ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to think about designing sustainable products.
How do to LCA/MCDA, general group project skills, some engineering-specific skills (but few)
I learned a lot about how to approach the issue of sustainability in the modern world.
I learned a great deal about what it means to sustainably design a system and how to rethink systems as a whole in order to accomplish this.
I learned the principles of green engineering, how to conduct life cycle analyses, and how to interact with and plan a long term project with a real client.

Better understanding of what sustainability is. How its applied in green engineering and green chemistry; the tools and values behind it all; and how to target sustainability in practice. Additionally, experience with the prototyping + engineering process, with a deeper appreciation for the material and physical sciences for impact.
Green engineering concepts and real-world focused approaches to sustainability.
None, this class should not be a requirement of environmental engineering, it was a waste of time.
I learned a lot about forming problem statements for design and thinking more clearly about what clients and consumers need and want vs. what the earth needs from a sustainability perspective.
I learned and practiced to think outside the box and thinking of the entire system when adopting more sustainable practices.
Very fun and engaging course! Learned many new skills such as arduino.

I learned about how to design using nature as an example, minimizing waste, new ways of thinking creatively, and about how to work with a client on a real world solution to a company's problem. The course was very much about a different kind of mindset when it came to design, prioritizing sustainability and health. Anastas is the best.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: cool idea, fun classroom, interesting lectures
Weaknesses: would've loved more skills workshops to have more concrete skills to take away from the class; some of the semester projects seemed like they weren't really engineering projects, which was hard to navigate; getting the semester projects and having deadlines before the midterm would've meant we could do much more substantial engineering work throughout the semester; we got very little feedback and it came very late, which was extremely frustrating.
I enjoyed it, no changes needed.

I think this course needs a rubric for all assignments. When my group for the midterm and final project asked for guidance, we sometimes received unclear and even contradictory instructions from the teaching team. In addition, I think working with a real world client is a very cool experience, but our client's specific issue that they wanted us to work on did not fit into the spirit of the course at all, and we spent several weeks being confused about how we were supposed to proceed before eventually being told to work on a different but related problem that we came up with ourselves. In the future, I hope the clients are given clear expectations of the deliverables for the class to get the most out of both their time and students' time.

The final project working with companies was cool, but it was definitely difficult to navigate the business side of this and the particular client my group worked with was not very helpful or easy to work with. There were challenges with the alignment between what the professors expected and what the clients expected, at least for my group, and it made it difficult to come up with a project that would make everyone happy.

The timing of this course was a bit strange to me.  Both the midterm and the final projects felt extremely rushed I don't see a reason why they both weren't introduced earlier, especially with the midterm.  That was really stressful.  Also, we should have had our personal meetings with the professors regarding our final project at least two weeks earlier than we did it was a really helpful meeting and should have come earlier in the design process.

The biggest strength of this course is the month-long design project at the end. Biggest weakness is that there is a lull, for about two weeks in the beginning of the semester, where the lectures are a little unfocused.

Strengths: Great opportunity to get hands-on experience in the CEID. Highly engaging with in-class exercises and design challenges. Learned more about whats it like to engineer actual prototypes and practice sustainability in real time. Both the midterm and final projects were great opportunities to learn. Extremely low time commitment (for better or for worse). Professors and TFs are extremely kind and understanding; candy and toys at classes for fun.

Weaknesses: Lectures, though concentrated in the first half of the semester, felt redundant and didnt have much value add to the course (e.g., executive leadership talk was irrelevant); it was often a lot of buzzwords being thrown around, and wouldve benefited from a greater focus on letting students ideate for themselves. In-class exercises could've benefited from greater instruction and guidance. Problem sets were short and had interesting content but were a waste of time. Feedback was scarce and delayed when given. There was plenty of collaboration, so it wouldve been nice for the Professors/TFs to make an effort to at least learn each of the students names.
It would be nice to know and meet with our clients earlier in the semester!

Strengths: The professors and teaching team are great. The final projects are cool because our clients are real companies. The course is paradigm-shifting for how you view sustainability and green engineering. The collaborative nature of the class was great and it did not feel difficult to talk with the teaching team or professors. 

Weaknesses: our grades on some assignments were not clear / took a while to get back, though overall it wasn't a huge worry because we were always getting feedback in class and were in touch with the TAs and Profs every class.

Strengths: Very hands work which is rare for environmental engineering classes. 
Weaknesses: The workload in the class is very backloaded, so most of the assignments are due in the second half of the semester, which is already very busy.

Strengths: The course has very good intentions (giving students practice working with "real world" clients and hands-on engineering). The content that Paul and Julie teach in lectures in the first half of the class is also very important (although a lot of it seemed like common sense to me, I think it would be especially valuable for non-environmental engineering majors to see). 
Weaknesses: To be honest, I didn't really learn much. There is a lot of potential for students to learn how to use all the machines in the CEID to build their prototypes. But many of the final projects simply involved pointing out obvious flaws in a company's current operation, or building an extremely simplified model. Working with real companies was nice but I think the executives probably learned more from our solution (ie seeing that their status quo is deeply flawed) than we learned from doing the project. Also, none of the companies actually wanted to adopt any of the solutions because it would be too expensive or not fit their current operation. 
For future years, PLEASE use a different software for LCA than Sustainable Minds. The software would crash at random times and there were some bugs with it making the LCAs take much longer than they could have. We probably spent 3-4 times longer figuring out the software than learning how to do LCAs.
I had no idea how I was doing in the class the whole time. They were incredibly slow with the grades and not at all transparent.

The course was well suited to student learning and collaboration, but some of the time felt like it could have been used more efficiently. The group activities and challenges as well as the final project were really fun!
midterm group project should differ a little as well in order to have some variety. it was a little hard doing the same project - sort of felt like we were competing with each other.
The homeworks were a bit long and sustainable minds was very difficult to work with.

strengths: super interesting, interactive, fun environment. They bring candy to class. Learning from Paul Anastas, the literal founder of green chemistry, was amazing. They also lined up great companies to work with for our final projects.  
weaknesses: basically no grades were shown until the very end, it was a bit unorganized, and the LCA class was very dry

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It was okay. Nice for an elective.
Yes -- it's a cool and unique class that you can choose how much you put into!
Yes, I liked the course.
Yes, I think there was a lot of creative thinking development that people would really appreciate.
Yes. Great course that teaches you a unique skillset for just the right amount of work.

Yes, generally. Theres no other class at Yale that lets you play with spaghetti and marshmallows as a learning exercise. Prepare to be actively moving around the CEID, working with new people, pitching, and building things each classno sitting down. But, there are a number of structural issues that the course team would benefit from fixing, for ENVE 360 to really live up to its hype in the syllabus and first few classes.

Yes; GESD is really interesting and Professors Zimmerman and Anastasia are great professors who care a lot about green engineering. The TAs are also very invested in the class and helped us in the projects. I found the final project itself to be not that interesting, since all of the projects were packaging-based. Other than that, the class is a lot of fun.

Yes! It's a great course. The course is foundational for learning about sustainability and green engineering -- and workload is reasonable and the assignments are project-based! The professors are engaging, extremely knowledgeable, and create a fun atmosphere in the class.
Yes, if you want a hands on class

If you are considering working in industry, either as an engineer or some type of manager/executive/consultant, this class is definitely important for you to take. You will learn that the metrics we currently use to assess good design are flawed, and you will learn how to design sustainably and think holistically about problems. Please take this class so you don't go into the world and create more problems than you solve.
Never. This was one of the most useless classes Ive taken here.
Definitely! If you're interested in green design this course will get you thinking from a different viewpoint. Would recommend.
yes. amazing and fun course at the CEID. loved the collaboration aspect.
Yes! Very fun class
Yes. It's quite unorganized but easy workload and you learn useful skills & ways of thinking related to innovation and sustainability.
